item.title: N. Korea fires on S. Korea, killing 1 and injuring 15
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Why is it so odd that China is pissed off when the US sends ships so close to China and it’s allies, when the US was pissed off when the Soviets sent missiles to Cuba?

Or:

Why is it so odd that North Korea is pissed off when South Korea sends ships so close to North Korea, when the US was pissed off when the Soviets sent missiles to Cuba?

item.title: N. Korea fires on S. Korea, killing 1 and injuring 15
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Frell:

China claimed it was communist, then switched to a capitalist economy, and still claims itself as communist.

They claim they are, yet their name and more importantly their system states otherwise: The People’s Republic of China. State owned property etc is part of a People’s Republic, the state that exists prior to a Communist state where the people own everything.

Read full topic

item.title: N. Korea fires on S. Korea, killing 1 and injuring 15
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Radeon:

[quote author=Frell link=topic=466084.msg3410086#msg3410086 date=1290622857]IIRC our mission in Afghan was just to take care of Al Qaeda, until we found out Saddam played a role.

Holly shit, I don’t even[/quote]
I was most likely wrong, our debates never forced me into research about Afghanistan, lol. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001–present) I just said it in an extreme nutshell.

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:37, topic:369968”][quote author=Frell link=topic=466084.msg3410086#msg3410086 date=1290622857]
Seeing as how every communist state there ever was has practically collapsed, that plays a good example also. In capitalist countries people are greedy because they can be, you can have anything you want. In communist countries everything is limited.
[/quote]

No country ever got as far as being Communist, they never got further then a People’s Republic.[/quote]
China claimed it was communist, then switched to a capitalist economy, and still claims itself as communist.

item.title: N. Korea fires on S. Korea, killing 1 and injuring 15
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:32, topic:369968”]Why do people always say that about communism when the same goes for democracy?

Name me a country with a true democracy? That’s actually fair. Communisms major problem was people are inherently greedy, the same goes for democracy as it seems to support greed and capitalism. America being the finest example.

I’m not defending communism, I’m merely pointing out that you’re a victim of democracy if you’re stupid enough to think the country you live in is actually really any fairer and better than these communist states.[/quote]
Seeing as how every communist state there ever was has practically collapsed, that plays a good example also. In capitalist countries people are greedy because they can be, you can have anything you want. In communist countries everything is limited.

[quote=“Greeny, post:29, topic:369968”][quote author=Frell link=topic=466084.msg3409730#msg3409730 date=1290579700]

US will always try to be in other peoples business because US will always see itself as the king of the universe.

No, but the 2 conflicts we didn’t stick our nose into escalated into World Wars. And you don’t consider NK threatening to use nukes as a problem for the world? Vietnam we were asked for help, and Korea we helped repel an invasion. Whats left?

I guarantee Obama will try to be involved at some point… Our troops will shift from the Afghanistan to Korea…

Given the consequences the US has faced from Iraq and Afghanistan. I doubt the US will ever forcefully occupy a country ever again. After retreating from Afghanistan in 2014, if the US gets involved in any other war it will most likely be limited to air strikes and special forces.
[/quote]The US already has 900k troops stationed in Korea.

Is that an exaggeration? IIRC it was more like 28k…

The first part of that post was really, really dumb. However that aside. Yes 28,000 currently stationed there however, I think if South Korea were attacked the US has some kind of agreement to send like 600k troops over for protection (that’s the number appearing in various places on the internet).

N.Korea couldn’t engage the US, but it could defend the shit out of itself on the ground. The US might have a great army but turf wars in Vietnam, Afghanistan and Iraq can tell you one thing - people will fight for their country and their freedom. And they will fight to the death.

Terrorism and guerilla warfare are the most devastating counter tactics to any nations acting as “world police”. An army like the US’s has so much manpower and technology - enemies know they’re too powerful to ever directly engage any of their forces. Scare tactics by blowing a few limbs off soldiers when they’re walking down quiet streets is a brutal but clever way to go. If you tactically occupied N.Korea it would probably go from militarised dictatorship nation to another Iraq; enter the hordes of insurgents from China, Russia and anywhere else.[/quote]
Im going to take a wild guess and say NK isn’t just a big desert like Iraq and Afghanistan are. Not only that, but our enemy will have a uniform, unlike vietnam and I&A.

Greeny:

N.Korea couldn’t engage the US, but it could defend the shit out of itself on the ground. The US might have a great army but turf wars in Vietnam, Afghanistan and Iraq can tell you one thing - people will fight for their country and their freedom. And they will fight to the death.

IIRC our mission in Afghan was just to take care of Al Qaeda, until we found out Saddam played a role. Either way, the only ones fighting for their freedom are the ones that are listening to intense propaganda that is used as a mouthpiece for Al Qaeda just like Aljazeera. Where they report fake articles about us bombing weddings etc, changing our motive of why we’re there so the people think theyre all going to die. But you’re right, the ones who buy into do put up a fight.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EV0pN-LaW6E - real interesting clip.

Read full topic

Name me a country with a true democracy? That’s actually fair. Communisms major problem was people are inherently greedy, the same goes for democracy as it seems to support greed and capitalism. America being the finest example.

I’m not defending communism, I’m merely pointing out that you’re a victim of democracy if you’re stupid enough to think the country you live in is actually really any fairer and better than these communist states.[/quote]

Actually, true Communism comes closer to true Democracy then the form of Democracy we have today.

item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:25, topic:369968”][quote author=Miss Silabsoft link=topic=466084.msg3409718#msg3409718 date=1290578632]
US will always try to be in other peoples business because US will always see itself as the king of the universe.
[/quote]
No, but the 2 conflicts we didn’t stick our nose into escalated into World Wars. And you don’t consider NK threatening to use nukes as a problem for the world? Vietnam we were asked for help, and Korea we helped repel an invasion. Whats left?

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=466084.msg3409713#msg3409713 date=1290578087]

I guarantee Obama will try to be involved at some point… Our troops will shift from the Afghanistan to Korea…

Given the consequences the US has faced from Iraq and Afghanistan. I doubt the US will ever forcefully occupy a country ever again. After retreating from Afghanistan in 2014, if the US gets involved in any other war it will most likely be limited to air strikes and special forces.
[/quote]The US already has 900k troops stationed in Korea.

Is that an exaggeration? IIRC it was more like 28k…[/quote]

The first part of that post was really, really dumb. However that aside. Yes 28,000 currently stationed there however, I think if South Korea were attacked the US has some kind of agreement to send like 600k troops over for protection (that’s the number appearing in various places on the internet).

N.Korea couldn’t engage the US, but it could defend the shit out of itself on the ground. The US might have a great army but turf wars in Vietnam, Afghanistan and Iraq can tell you one thing - people will fight for their country and their freedom. And they will fight to the death.

Terrorism and guerilla warfare are the most devastating counter tactics to any nations acting as “world police”. An army like the US’s has so much manpower and technology - enemies know they’re too powerful to ever directly engage any of their forces. Scare tactics by blowing a few limbs off soldiers when they’re walking down quiet streets is a brutal but clever way to go. If you tactically occupied N.Korea it would probably go from militarised dictatorship nation to another Iraq; enter the hordes of insurgents from China, Russia and anywhere else.
